thread.title: Cancer Council reports surge in Queensland cases, says a third preventable - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
thread.title_full: Cancer Council reports surge in Queensland cases, says a third preventable - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

title: Cancer Council reports surge in Queensland cases, says a third preventable - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Cancer Council reports surge in Queensland cases, says a third preventable Posted February 20, 2017 11:10:07 Map: QLD 
The number of cancer cases in Queensland has risen by more than 20 per cent in three decades, new figures suggest. 
The Cancer Council said its evidence revealed that a third of the state's cases could have been prevented. 
Nevertheless, it said, survival was at an all-time high, at 70 per cent. 
The number of diagnoses each year went from 8,277 in 1982 to more than 27,000 cases in 2014, according to the council's latest data. 
Once growth and age adjustments were taken out, that equated to a 23 per cent rise. 
Cancer Council chief executive Jeff Dunn said about a third of cancers were preventable. Photo: Malignant cells in breast cancer, which is the third most common type of cancer. (Supplied) 
"If we didn't smoke, if we were sun smart and we looked after our physical activity and maintained a healthy body-weight and participated in recommended screening, the number of people diagnosed by cancer would be reduced by a third," Professor Dunn said. 
Prostate cancer remains the most common form of cancer, followed by melanoma, breast and bowel cancer. 
Although lung cancer is not the most frequent diagnosis, it accounts for most deaths â€” 21 per cent. 
About 8,700 Queenslanders die from cancer each year. 
Professor Dunn said survival rates for cancer hit 70 per cent for the first time. 
"That's tremendous news," he said. 
"When we first started collecting these stats, the average five-year survival rate for cancer was just under 50 per cent, and now it's at 70 per cent, so there is good news."
